George Gershwin: An American in Paris is a jazz-influenced symphonic poem by the American composer [George_Gershwin|George Gershwin] , written in 1928 .
Inspired by the time [George_Gershwin|Gershwin] had spent in Paris , it evokes the sights and energy of the French capital in the 1920s and is one of [George_Gershwin|his] best-known compositions .
Inspired by the time [George_Gershwin|Gershwin] had spent in Paris , it evokes the sights and energy of the French capital in the 1920s and is one of [George_Gershwin|his] best-known compositions .
[George_Gershwin|Gershwin] composed An American in Paris on commission from the conductor [Walter_Damrosch|Walter Damrosch] .
[George_Gershwin|Gershwin] completed the orchestration on November 18 , less than four weeks before the work 's premiere .

[George_Gershwin|Gershwin] collaborated on the original program notes with the critic and composer Deems Taylor , noting that : " My purpose here is to portray the impression of an American visitor in Paris as [George_Gershwin|he] strolls about the city and listens to various street noises and absorbs the French atmosphere . Although most modern audiences have heard the taxi horns using the notes A , B , C and D , it has recently come to light that [George_Gershwin|Gershwin] 's intention was to have used the notes A4 , B4 , D5 , and A4 .
It is likely that in labeling the taxi horns as A , B , C and D with circles , [George_Gershwin|he] may have been referring to the use of the four different horns and not the notes that they played .

Walter Damrosch: [George_Gershwin|Gershwin] composed An American in Paris on commission from the conductor [Walter_Damrosch|Walter Damrosch] .
[Walter_Damrosch|He] scored the piece for the standard instruments of the symphony orchestra plus celesta , saxophones , and automobile horns .
